instruction: 1. Welcome to the mitmproxy tutorial. In this lesson we cover the interception of requests.
2. We first need to configure mitmproxy to intercept requests.
3. Press `i` to prepopulate mitmproxy’s command prompt with `set intercept ''`.
4. We use the flow filter expression `~u <regex>` to only intercept specific URLs.
5. Additionally, we use the filter `~q` to only intercept requests, but not responses.
6. We combine both flow filters using `&`.
7. Enter `~u /Dunedin & ~q` between the quotes of the `set intercept` command and press `ENTER`.
8. The bottom bar shows that the interception has been configured.
9. Let’s generate a request using `curl` in a separate terminal.
10. You see a new line in in the list of flows.
11. The new flow is displayed in red to indicate that it has been intercepted.
12. Put the focus (`>>`) on the intercepted flow. This is already the case in our example.
13. Press `a` to resume this flow without making any changes.
14. Submit another request and focus its flow.
15. Press `X` to kill this flow, i.e., discard it without forwarding it to its final destination `wttr.in`.
16. In the next lesson you will learn to modify intercepted flows.
